content: The Act is titled the "Bullying Redress and Verified Enforcement Act" or the "BRAVE Act." It amends Title IX of the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 to include reporting requirements on bullying. The "BRAVE Act" amends Title IX to include reporting requirements on bullying. A local educational agency must report bullying acts within 7 business days. The "BRAVE Act" requires local educational agencies to report bullying incidents, including details of the acts, any reference to protected characteristics, and the response by agency employees. An exception is made for employees informed of bullying by students. The "BRAVE Act" mandates local educational agencies to report bullying incidents, with an exception for employees who are informed of bullying by students but are asked not to report it. The "BRAVE Act" requires local educational agencies to designate an individual to receive reports of bullying and inform all employees of the contact information. Within 60 days of receiving a report, the designated individual must inform all employees of the bullying acts and the response taken. The "BRAVE Act" mandates local educational agencies to designate a contact person for bullying reports. Within 60 days, this person must inform all employees of the bullying incidents and the response taken, excluding any student's personal information. Additionally, the agency must publish quarterly reports for students and parents. The "BRAVE Act" requires local educational agencies to publish quarterly reports summarizing reported bullying incidents and the responses by agency employees, excluding any student's personal information. The "BRAVE Act" mandates local educational agencies to publish quarterly reports summarizing responses to bullying incidents by agency employees, while excluding any student's personal information. The public must be informed of their right to file a complaint under subsection (b)(2), with an exception for cases where publication would reveal personal details. Each local educational agency must annually review bullying policies for schools served, and as a condition of receiving funds under the "BRAVE Act," they are required to publish reports on responses to bullying incidents while protecting student privacy. Local educational agencies must annually certify compliance with bullying policies and submit quarterly reports to the Secretary to receive funds under the "BRAVE Act." Additionally, the Assistant Secretary of the Office of Civil Rights for the Department of Education must establish a procedure for complaints related to non-compliance with this section. The Assistant Secretary must establish a procedure for complaints regarding non-compliance with bullying policies, investigate complaints, and publish the procedure on the Department of Education's website. The Assistant Secretary will investigate complaints of non-compliance with bullying policies in local educational agencies. If non-compliance is found, actions may include withholding funds and issuing a complaint for compliance. The Assistant Secretary may take actions such as withholding funds, issuing complaints, or entering into compliance agreements with local educational agencies to ensure compliance with bullying policies. These actions are authorized under sections 455, 456, and 457. The Assistant Secretary can take actions to ensure compliance with bullying policies by working with local educational agencies, similar to actions authorized under sections 455, 456, and 457 of the General Education Provisions Act. Information about complaints must be made public within 60 days on the Department of Education's website. The Assistant Secretary must provide information about bullying complaints on the Department of Education's website, including a description of any protected characteristic involved and excluding any personally identifiable information. The term 'bullying' is defined as any severe form of harassment. The term 'bullying' is defined as any severe, pervasive, or persistent act by one student or a group towards another student causing harm or concern for their well-being, property, or mental health. The term 'bullying' is defined as any severe, pervasive, or persistent act by one student or a group towards another student causing harm or concern for their well-being, property, or mental health, including actions that lead to the withdrawal or avoidance of school services or activities. The term 'protected characteristic' includes race, color, sex, religion, national origin, disability, gender, gender identity, and sexual orientation.
